n the Western world,

149.text:

through this golden time,

we are, as most humans,
want to go to the place of risk.

163.text:
And I'd argue that our number one

167.text:
Some would say it's food:

171.text: There's some who would say it's water.

membranes turn sea water potable.

solar energy has reached the one per cent

Solar cells have reduced the cost

225.text:
Lack of meaningful work,
I'd argue, is our number one risk.

229.text: It is who we are as a people.

233.text:
It's what makes you and me,
it's our evolution.

238.text: Meaningful work is a beautiful thing

240.text:
because it is individually defined
by each one of us,

244.text: and what it means for each one of us.

246.text:
This is not a story about anything
other than you and me as individuals.

252.text: We define what we mean by meaningful work.

255.text:
For some of us, it might be
an economic engine

257.text:
so we can play and we can grow
and learn and procreate;

262.text:
for others it might be
a yearning for significance;

265.text:
for others it might be
an ability to serve humanity.

268.text: It is our choice, who we are.

272.text:
When I was telling you this story,
about me selling the company to IBM,

277.text:
that should have been my crowning moment:
the day the deal closed.

282.text: It was the saddest day of my life.

285.text: It took me months to recover.

288.text:
My 40-year-old friend, lover, wife,
best friend finally lost her temper at me.

297.text:
and more than half those nights,
I fell asleep crying.

306.text: simply because jobs are being decimated

That's the noise you hear in the US

Somebody no less

Between artificial intelligence,

some of the stuff

349.text:
Before I get there, let's describe
for a second who we are:

352.text: We're mammals, as we've learnt today.

356.text: But we're different from other mammals

358.text:
because we have this notion
of intelligence and conscience.

360.text:
We have the ability to dream,
and create these mental constructs.

367.text:
These mental constructs
is what makes us happy,

369.text: it makes us who we are.

371.text:
Everything of importance in our life,
I'd argue, is a mental construct.

378.text:
Nation states are simply lines
in the sand, or on a map.

383.text:
Faith, religion - I would argue,
family is a mental construct.

392.text:
And so the two mental constructs I wish
to change and break today are as follows:

400.text:
meaningful work has been with us
forever and will be with us forever.

407.text: Jobs are simply a subset of work.

411.text:
The word "job" itself is less
than 400 years old,

414.text: and did not come into our lexicon

416.text:
until the beginning of the Industrial
Revolution, about 250 years ago.

425.text:
But when we lose a job, all we can do
is find another one in the same vertical,

432.text:
or move to different vertical
and take our skills with us, or migrate.

438.text:
This country is rich
in its heritage of migrants

441.text:
creating the wealth
and the greatness of this nation,

444.text: and the city is rooted in that.

448.text: But jobs do not make work, necessarily.

451.text: Work is something we create for ourselves.

456.text: This paradigm shift has to change,

460.text:
because the people in society
are changing alongside it:

465.text: In the last 30 years in the United States,

468.text:
the working population, defined
between the ages of 22 and 60,

475.text:
The number of full-time jobs
increased by 180 per cent.

479.text:
Unemployment rate
still sits at 5 per cent.

483.text:
It's this whole category
of independent workers.

486.text:
People went out there
and created work for themselves.

489.text:
In the days of old, it would be
the temporary staff,

492.text:
the temporary secretary, 
the day labourer.

496.text: Today, it's way more than that:

497.text:
it's the entrepreneur;
it's a professional athlete;

504.text:
it is the academic professor
who creates literature

508.text:
and course curriculum,

515.text:
That's where our dreams are,
that's where our aspirations are,

520.text:
that's what our identity is,
that's who we are as human beings.

526.text:
Let's break that mental construct
that jobs equal work.

530.text: No, jobs are a subset of work.

539.text:
He creates an environment
where work is created,

542.text:
and we go out there and seek
the jobs that somebody gives us.

546.text:
That's the mental construct
we have to break.

549.text:
The second mental construct
we have to break

553.text:
is in two pieces:
it's called entitlement.

558.text:
And part 2 of that is, forget it:
entitlement is here to stay.

565.text: From the moment we were born

567.text:
we were entitled to suckle
at our mother's breast that gave us life!

575.text:
As we have grown through society,
different programs have come in.

583.text:
When we were a junior species,
we relied on communities and families

588.text:
to provide for us when
we couldn't provide for ourselves.

592.text: Then we relied on the Government.

596.text:
We need to discard all forms
of social programs,

608.text:
Which is the individual right
for every citizen

611.text:
to unconditionally get an income
from the state, on a regular basis.

616.text:
As a capitalist, as a business owner,
I demand that out of my leader.

623.text: I am willing to pay higher taxes for that.

626.text:
Without it, we will destroy
the fabric of society as we know it today.

631.text:
Universal basic income is not about
increasing dependence;

636.text:
it's about meeting the Maslow's hierarchy

641.text:
Universal basic income

646.text:
Universal basic income

Our greatest innovations weren't from
the hungry, homeless people

whether it be the Internet,

or the smartphone,

These weren't homeless

who lived in a nice house

This notion that this entitlement

688.text:
And so you and me, together,

Which is, let's think of work
to take us to our highest aspirations

701.text:
And let us demand from our leaders

The data that came out

We have to change, we have to demand

Wherever our destiny takes us,
